title: Do you think that prisoners should be forced to work? - Quora

response.answer_text: Hi Matt. Not very many would refuse work where I did my time. Many just need some fresh air (outside grounds, rec orderly, car pool maintenance). Others look at it as more of a “contact” to “contact” sort of thing. Making deals cross-compound, passing contraband an so forth. I worked in the chow hall (both the front and the back) for about a year, but I had to stop when I went to medical to check out some dizziness and found out I had A-fib (missing a beat or two or three in my heart). I began the rest of my “career” as a houseman cleaning the windows in the dorm and the officer station “bubble”. Forty-five minutes and hardest part of the day was over. There was no physical force or retribution toward an inmate if he refused to work. There was, however, an incentive to convince them. Usually it would be time in “jail” and then you’d be in the DR Squad (Disciplinary Report) for 2–3 months. SOMEBODY’S got to take out the trash. If they didn’t report to the squad, then they’re back in jail. When you are in jail, you are out of touch with other, more profitable things. We had a P.R.I.D.E company going at Calhoun C.I. for printing, mailing, and digital imaging. The major client was the Florida School System. Calendars of events, desk covers, time-tables. Stuff like that. Prison Rehabilitative Industries and Diversified Enterprises, Inc. That’s what the acronym stands for, and it was the highest paying job on the compound, usueally fetching 35 to 40 cents an hour. PRIDE Enterprises The prison system in Arizona (going back several years) used inmates as reservations agents for American Airlines. Same training as the people outside the walls, but those outside the walls were making $15/hour while the inmate made something like 50 cents an hour doing the very same work and taking the same irate passengers and travel agencies from time to time. And they answered the phone the same way. “Thank you for calling American Airlines. My name is Steve, how may I help you?” At our P.R.I.D.E. the phone would be answered, “Pride services, inmate MacEwen, how may I help you?”

Most should in General population. There are plenty of jobs, and GED classes. Inmates in what many call “Super Max.” are in there for committing some violent crime in prison or belonging to a prison gang. They should NOT be assigned to work and they should NOT be allowed to earn good time credits. They are a proven security risk to staff and other inmates. The same applies for Death Row inmates.

No. You are there to do time. That sucks enough. But you shouldn’t be forced into slave labor to profit companies that have business with the state. That takes it too far. Sadly, it is Constitutional. The exception to the law against slavery is that prisoners can be slave laborers.

I have a close friend who is currently a guest of the Federal Government. She says that jobs are treasured. There are a lot more inmates than there are jobs, she’s lucky if she can work 10 hours a week, for $.50 an hour. Add to that the fact that prices in the commissary are twice what they would be in a supermarket, a bag of chips every week.

It depends how it is done. The best prisons have prisoners work at real jobs for real wages. To try to make money off of prisoners is immoral. To rent them out for cheap labor to companies is immoral. But no one wants to sit around. The best is to have a win win situation. The best would be to do significant work that really applies after prison instead of doing work that accomplishes nothing for no wages as is done now.

For the most part yes they are required to work. This is the only way for some inmates to get what's called 'gained time's. Gain time is the time off the end of their sentence which will in some cases allow them to get out earlier. Interestingly enough, depending on the State the inmate is incarcerated in. He or she will be required to work, but not get paid for it. In NY State inmates receive a small payment for the work they do. However, in Florida, the inmate is again required to work. But does not GET paid at all..

I reckon that the work should be hard and the management of same ruthless. Make prison undesirable on all levels and tell and show the community. There needs to be more reason to not want to go to prison. Take all the nice out of it.

Different states and counties have different sentencing laws when it comes to how much good time is allotted. For instance an inmate sentenced to thirty days in jail would only have to be in custody eighteen days and would receive twelve days of good time reduction for working from the original thirty day sentence. I'm not real familiar with state or federal time computation, but in the county I worked in good time was only given to inmates that worked. An inmate could refuse to work and they would subsequently lose all the good time sentence reduction benefits.
